abstract.text: is a helper that allows you to read files without blocking the calling thread.

inlineContent.text: returning claiming a file is readable does not mean that the
data is already available in the kernel’s memory. In other words, a
from a file can still block even if
reported as readable. This behaviour is also documented behaviour:
: “Regular files shall always poll TRUE for reading and writing.”
: “epoll is simply a faster poll(2), and can be used wherever the latter is used since it shares the same semantics.”
: “Returns when the file pointer is not at the end of file.”
helps to work around this issue by maintaining its own thread pool that is used to read the data
from the files into memory. It will then hand the (in-memory) data back which makes it available without the possibility
